Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Evolutionary Origins of Chiton Shell-eyes: Integrating Structure, Function, and Gene Expression within a Phylogenetic Context
Award.AbstractNarration:
Fundamental questions in biology include: How do complex traits, such as eyes, evolve through changes in underlying sub-components? What are the transitional steps in function that link simple light-sensitive structures and complex image-forming eyes? The studies supported by this award use chitons (Mollusca: Polyplacophora) in an integrative research approach to ask how and why eyes evolve. Specifically, the proposal addresses: 1) changes in genotype associated with the origin of new light-interacting structures and 2) relationships between new light-interacting structures and new light-influenced behaviors. Integrative research on chitons will help advance the field of biomaterials. Studying the aragonite lenses of chitons will help researchers learn how animals build precisely shaped structures through the process of biomineralization. Studying the origin of eyes in chitons will also help counter popular misconceptions about evolution by demonstrating how complex traits evolve through stepwise processes. Undergraduate and graduate training, as well as public outreach efforts are also integrated into this project.

The research objectives for this award follow the unique sensory organs (aesthetes) embedded in chiton shell plates: photoreceptors, eyespots, and eyes (with aragonite lenses). Specifically, the award supports studies to: (1) Identify the molecular components responsible for light-detection in eyeless chitons and establish the visually-influenced behaviors displayed by these animals; (2) Characterize the pigments and pigment-producing genes associated with the eyespots of certain chitons and establish the light-influenced behaviors unique to these species; and (3) Investigate the molecular components that confer spatial vision in chitons with eyes and identify genes that may be associated with the development of their aragonite lenses. Results from the studies will be published in peer-reviewed journals and disseminated at scientific meetings.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit: Chitons (Mollusca: Polyplacophora) are a promising system in which to study how and why eyes evolve because living species have sensory structures embedded in their shell plates that may represent separate steps of the gradual evolution of eyes. Some species only have simple photoreceptors, some have eyespots, and others have eyes. We asked how the eyes of chitons evolved by seeking associations between changes in gene expression and origins of new light-interacting structures. By studying the molecular components of sensory transduction across living chitons and by reconstructing ancestral states, we found the eyes of chitons evolved from organs that likely functioned as multimodal sensors. Intriguingly, the eyes and eyespots of chitons express the molecular components of fewer sensory transduction pathways than the simpler sensory structures from which they both evolved, indicating complex relationships between different levels of biological organization during eye evolution.

 

Broader Impact: Chitons produce a wide range of structures through biomineralization, including image-forming lenses made of aragonite and iron-coated teeth. Towards our goal of understanding how chitons produce these structures, the grant helped support a collaboration to sequence the genome of the eyed chiton Acanthopleura granulata. The grant contributed to the training of a diverse, globally competitive STEM workforce, including the training of a post-doctoral scholars (J. Cannon).

 

Dr. Kingston will be starting as an Assistant Professor at Tulsa University in Fall 2020, a tenure-track, research-focused position. The grant also contributed to the training of one Ph.D. student (Daniel Chappell, in progress), two M.S. students (Natalie Sanchez and Jamie Clark, both graduated), and seven undergraduate students. Among these undergraduates, one is in medical school and three are pursuing research-focused PhDs in biology. With support from the grant, PI Speiser engaged the public by, among other activities, providing interviews to writers at the New York Times, The Atlantic, and National Geographic and by providing material for exhibits such as those at the Natural History Museum (London) titled “Colour and Vision” and the Smallest Mollusk Museum.


Products: PI Speiser has published ten papers from this award so far (with more to be submitted for review soon). These publications include articles in Evolution, Journal of Experimental Biology, and Integrative and Comparative Biology. Undergraduate researchers in PI Speiser’s lab were first authors on two of these papers: Olivia Harris on a paper published in Journal of the Royal Society Interface (in 2019) and Hayley Miller on a paper published in Current Biology (in 2019). Also as part of this project, PI Speiser’s lab developed an automated and efficient method for electroretinography (the subject of a forthcoming publication). The award helped support 1) a symposium titled “Neuroethology of Distributed Visual Systems: How do many-eyed animals perceive the world?” for the 2018 International Conference of Neuroethology (held 15-20 July 2018 in Brisbane, Australia) and 2) a virtual symposium for Biological Bulletin on “New insights from genetic datasets on the function and evolution of visual systems” (symposium published August 2017).
